conclusion: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, represented by the slope of the velocity-time graph.
The graph shows velocity (v) in m·s⁻¹ on the y-axis and time (t) in seconds on the x-axis.
From 0 to 1 second, the velocity is constant at 2 m·s⁻¹.
From 1 to 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 m·s⁻¹ to 0 m·s⁻¹.
From 2 to 3 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 0 m·s⁻¹ to -2 m·s⁻¹.

premise: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, represented by the slope of the velocity-time graph.
conclusion: During the interval from 1 to 3 seconds, the velocity changes at a constant rate (linear decrease).

premise: Initial velocity (at t = 1s): v₁ = 2 m·s⁻¹; Final velocity (at t = 3s): v₂ = -2 m·s⁻¹; Time interval: Δt = 3s - 1s = 2s
From 1s to 2s: Velocity changes from 2 m·s⁻¹ to 0 m·s⁻¹
conclusion: Acceleration for this segment, a₁ = (0 - 2)/1 = -2 m·s⁻²

premise: From 2s to 3s: Velocity changes from 0 m·s⁻¹ to -2 m·s⁻¹
conclusion: Acceleration for this segment, a₂ = (-2 - 0)/1 = -2 m·s⁻²

premise: Both segments have the same acceleration of -2 m·s⁻².
conclusion: The acceleration of the particle during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds is -2 m·s⁻².
